evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25, as documented in the hist_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is inferred from lack of warnings and positioning rather than explicit communication failure documentation
defeaters: If evidence showed timely and effective communication or warnings from crew members preventing the incident
If the headset operator or wingman had communicated clearly and effectively
If the tug instructor had acknowledged or responded to communications

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows the flight crew communicated with the headset operator (H1), and the headset operator and wingman were positioned near the tug (H3), but the tug instructor did not receive any warning from them about the impending collision (H8), indicating a communication/coordination breakdown during the pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct transcript or recordings of communications; reliance on post-event statements and positioning; ambiguity about the quality and timing of communications

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is present and observable in the hist_t2_interim data.

defeaters: Evidence showing mechanical or control system faults in the aircraft during the incident
Data logs or maintenance records indicating mechanical/control failure
Explicit mention of mechanical/control failure in the hist_t2_interim data
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the hist_t2_interim data indicates the presence or observability of a mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25; the history items describe a pushback incident involving human factors and procedural issues but do not mention mechanical or control system failures (H1-H9).

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency is present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t2_interim period on 12-25.

assumptions: The insufficiency of the visual stop signal implies a marking or environmental deficiency
The TRP marking and clearance described in H7 applies to the incident context
defeaters: Direct evidence showing the TRP markings were clear and sufficient during the incident
Evidence that the visual signals were adequate and observed by the tug driver

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 describes the TRP marking and clearance, while H8 indicates the visual stop signal was insufficient and not always visible, suggesting a marking or environmental deficiency contributed to the incident.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct observation or report explicitly stating the environmental or marking deficiency was present and observable on 12-25 during hist_t2_interim period.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim scope.

defeaters: If there was evidence that the deviation was not documented or observable in the specified scope
If the TRP or procedural standards were different than described
If the incident occurred outside the 12-25 hist_t2_interim scope

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The history evidence directly documents the procedural deviation during pushback execution with the trainee driver stopping and the instructor taking over (H2), the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier (H4), and details about the TRP location and clearance (H7). The tug instructor's comments on signaling and lack of warnings (H8) and the trainee's qualifications and awareness (H9) further support the observation and documentation of the deviation within the specified scope.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence is clear and direct

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors and crew resource management failures identified in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim case.

assumptions: Visual signals are a key part of crew resource management communication
Lack of warnings from wingman and headset operator indicates coordination breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given timely
If the crew had sufficient experience and training to prevent breakdown
If the incident was caused by mechanical failure rather than communication issues

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication methods (visual signals) were insufficient and that key personnel (wingman, headset operator) did not warn of impending collision (H8). The trainee driver was relatively inexperienced (H9), and the instructor had to take over (H2, H3). These factors align with known human factors and crew resource management failures involving communication and coordination breakdowns.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit analysis linking observed communication issues to established human factors and CRM failure frameworks

node.statement: The mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 in the hist_t2_interim scope.

defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical or control system malfunction or failure during the incident, that would change the assessment.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates any mechanical or control failure related to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the pushback; the events describe human actions and procedural details without mention of mechanical/control issues (H1-H9).
